And served with white bread, just like any good fried chicken should be.I wasn't expecting much off the sides, as most Yelp-ers seem to think they are lackluster, but we had the baked beans, the coleslaw, and the mac and cheese and thought all were really, really good.They also have sweet tea, which any self-respecting southern restaurant should have!It's bit pricey, is the only drawback. We paid like $55 for lunch for two. I definitely don't remember paying that at the fried chicken shops back home, but I'd pay it again cause, well, it was damn good!

26.description: A little piece of Austin in Chicago! This place is insanely delicious and I literally can't believe it here!!! So good!!

25.description: Soft opening was the reason why I stopped by. Maybe I just enjoy my waiters sweat buckets and stumble while placing my orders but this place was popping. Chicken smelled like crispy goodness and came out in 10 minutes. And you know, the chicken really wasn't bad. It wasn't great either. The crispiness of the skin and batter had a solid crunch, the aroma was fragrant and the white/dark meat was juicy enough that it didn't feel dry. It was a good meal. My only trouble was remembering anything about this place. It just didn't stand out.

12.description: Say hello to smokin' hot, amazing freshly fried chicken right here in Chicago. I've heard some buzz about this place and come here with some cousins ASAP.We had a party of 8 and we ordered 24 pieces of dark meat, 3 per head. We also ordered a few large sides (which come in big styrofoam tubs). Here's the breakdown:18 piece dark6 piece darkFried pickles (appetizer)Large mac n' cheeseLarge cole slawLarge fries (seasoned)Medium potato saladI was a little bummed that they were out of greens, but the mac n' cheese and the slaw were great complements to the chicken (which had a spicy kick). For me it wasn't too spicy, especially since I washed it down with some sweet tea. (Refreshing like whoa.)Their sweet tea is GOOD here, seconded by my cousin who's spent some time in Nashville and loves southern food. Definitely order it with your chicken, and it comes with a take-home cup. They have Louisiana hot sauce, which you don't even really need since the chicken was delicious on its own.Chicken gets five stars. Everything was so fresh and came out piping hot, the skin a golden brown crisp - like it was breaded and fried upon ordering. Since they cook to order, your chicken will take a little longer to be ready than say, KFC, but Gus' cannot be compared to a fast food chain. It's like, top notch fried chicken.Their servers will give each person plastic cutlery and foam plates, so it has a very casual feel like you're at a picnic. Service was kind and our server made sure our cups were filled with sweet tea, even bringing a few extra pitchers because of our large party.As someone who appreciates really good fried chicken, Gus' is on point. No wonder they are "world famous" haha. I believe it. According to their website, they have 12 locations across 6 states (GA, MS, AR, TN, IL, TX)... 1 amazing recipe. And they're still planning to expand.To all the fried chicken lovers in Chicago, this place is for you. Next time I'm back I hope they'll have the greens, but God bless you Gus and thanks for chicken done right!

59.description: Darn good fried chicken. Not the best I've eaten, but darn good. A bit salty (obviously brined) with a good crunch and slow-arriving heat. Sides were OK. KFC-like slaw, boring beans, but mac was good. A bit pricey at $17+ for a half chibken plate, though it included two sides and a slice of Wonder Bread. Overall, I think I'd probably go back.

21.description: My good friend hyped this place up half a year before they opened and how they would drive from chicago to Memphis for this amazing chicken couple times a year. It is finally in Chicago and I have to say I am thoroughly impressed. Definitely one of the best fried chickens I ever had. Took some home later that night and nuked it and it was just as good. I little on the salty side but love the spicy kick. A bit pricier than your average fried chicken but it is definitely worth trying.

17.description: When to go: Anytime before 6 for no wait. Preferably weekdays. How many people to invite with you: 2-4How much money to bring: Around 20 per person or less! :)What you'll see: Beautiful exposed brick, an inviting neon sign out front, young wait staff who are super friendly, broken chairs, cheap napkins, cheap silverware, cheap paper plates. The southern charm striped table cloths. Now...what do ORDER!Fried Chicken- of course! Go with the plate. I loved the fried okra, the french fries were terrible and so was the potato salad so just stick to the original cold slaw and beans if you must. BE PATIENT- Your fried chicken comes fresh to you out of peanut oil so it's a bit of wait. I ate so much my stomach was hurting but I still took home a slice of pecan pie! You can get it hot or cold. It was perfect when we got home. I will def. go back! It's also nice to get fried chicken for cheap in the city.

10.description: Today was my first experience with Gus's and it was a really good one. As I scarfed down my chicken, I kept wondering how they manage to get so much flavor into it while keeping it tender. I don't know the answer---and I'm guessing they won't share their secret with me---but I didn't let that stop me from thoroughly enjoying the chicken. If all they sold were chicken, this would be a 5 star review. But the sides...whomp whomp. We had the mac and cheese, baked beans, greens, and fried okra. The beans are the only thing I'd eat again. Maybe they are so focused on infusing flavor into the chicken that everything else gets shafted? Though the sides were forgettable, I'm definitely coming back for more bird!  Also, the space is pretty well ventilated so I did not return to work smelling like grease.  That is a good thing.

5.description: Lol how is this place world famous?I mean the name is a total send off. The only thing they offer to the world is an incredible amount of pollution. CAUTION: ALL FOOD HERE IS SERVED ON STYROFOAM I'm baffled that I had a $50 meal served to me completely on disposables. How is this even legal? In a time where Chicago is banning the use of plastic bags, Gus's opens and practically defeats any progress we've made thus far.anyways, the chicken was alright. Both employees I talked to warned me about the chicken being very spicy - I felt totally lied to.  The chicken has little to no spice at all.  The baked beans served on the side were alright, but the coleslaw tasted fresh out of a can. Lol, not trying to diss this place too bad, but it was really mediocre. They need to step their sides up, they couldn't be any more basic. Parson's fried chicken in Logan is farrrrrrr better than Gus's. Hands down.

3.description: Just Like Daddy Used To MakeThank the GODS for Gus's World Famous Fried Chicken! There are no words to know how ecstatic I am that there is another fantastic fried chicken joint in Chicago and that I have discovered it. Between Harold's and Gus's WFFC, I can sleep at night knowing that whenever I need a taste of the south, all I need is to hop on the 66 bus and within 20 minutes I am home again. Figuratively.Location/Decor - tucked away on a strip on Fulton Market, Gus's WFFC is strategically placed out of the way of touristy destinations. This feat I particularly LOVE. You have to have done your research to know about this place because one does not simply "stumble upon" Gus's. I LOVE this neighborhood. Don't really know what the technical name is called (West Loop or West Town) but the industrial aesthetic I get from all the lofts and warehouses...it is goals. I would love to move here. The inside of Gus's matches its surrounding as well. Exposed piping in the ceiling, brick and wood planks against the walls. Rustic bars and bar tables and stools. I love it. Service - I had to dock a half star for the service. There were simply way too many patrons for the amount of wait/bar staff at Gus's. It took 10 minutes just for my waiter to ask for my drink. And 15 minutes after that before he got around to asking what we wanted to order. The food came out with haste, but the process just took entirely too long. It took even longer before he came to give our check and return our cards. It was only because it was super busy. That is a good thing and a bad thing. For the reasons I just wrote.Drinks - There is a full bar here. Unless someone buys me drinks however, I choose not to imbibe. I settled with a sweet tea (yum!) and my friend settled with a fountain drink. Standard.Food - im crying thinking about how amazing this chicken is.*2 piece white (one breast/one wing): This is the juiciest chicken with the crispiest skin. These people truly know how to brine! The flavor was ALL the way through the chicken! SO many times I have eaten fried chicken and people neglect to brine and the only flavor rests within the skin alone. For huge pieces of breasts - such as the ones at Gus's - this is problematic. But Gus's did it right! I drenched mine in hot sauce although there was just enough kick without it. But the hot sauce set it right over the top. 5 stars.*Mac and Cheese: SUPERB!!! Its not the traditional mac and cheese of the south but it is definitely still fantastic! I am used to having mac and cheese baked and crispy topping. Not sure if they do this here, but the topping wasnt crispy but had gooey melted cheese sprinkled over. NO processed cheese! All quality. 5 stars.*Cole Slaw. wonderful! No complaints. Standard. 3 stars.*bread: I wish places like this would either choose yeast rolls or biscuits. This slice of toast ruined the bread portion of the dinner. 1 star. *Chocolate Chess Pie - warm, gooey, creamy. A brownie in a pie. The crust was flavorless - which sucks - but the filling mixed with the ice cream provided for a great treat. The ice cream was hard as a brick but because the pie was hot, it melted easily.Price - less than twenty dollars with tip. superb.I will definitely return.

35.description: Just a bit spicy, crispy and fried up to order, Gus's is the new place in Chicago to sample us some Tennessee-an fried chicken. On a frigid day, I wouldn't be hesistant to take a piece and hold my hands over the top to warm up. Oh, my little tasty poultry hand warmer.You can order by the piece, plate or bucket. We got ourselves a plate which normally is a choice of 2 or 3 pieces along with 2 sides and bread. The staple side of sweet baked beans and creamy slaw complements perfectly with the spicy chicken. I also got to take a bite of greens (slightly spicy) and okra (wished they weren't cut and fried into tiny little pieces, lost the slime factor), The dark cuts of thigh and leg are satisfying, but opting for white cuts, in particular, the breast, is huge! I got to try all 3 and they are juicy, spicy and crispy. If you like fried chicken, you need to add this to your list. There ain't nothing like southern fried chicken, they know how to fry.

19.description: Kinda let down.The chicken's skin was tasty, but surprisingly dry.  Strange.  The meat itself was good and juicy, so if you got a bite of skin and meat, it balanced itself out a little better.  Be aware that the chicken will come out *incredibly* hot, so force yourself to let it cool for a bit.  My girlfriend doesn't like eating off the bone, so she ordered tenders.  I tried hers and I thought the chicken wasn't as good without the skin.I tried ordering just a breast and a leg, but my server brought me a plate with three pieces of chicken, beans and cole slaw.  (I don't care for beans and I thought the cole slaw wasn't very good.)I did like their fries, which were pretty thick and nicely seasoned.  Their macaroni and cheese is creamy and excellent.You get your food on styrofoam plates with plastic silverware that isn't really up to the task of taking apart the chicken, so that's weird.  I get that they're trying to replicate some sort of run-down Southern chicken shack, but this location must have cost a fortune to build, so let's stop pretending.  It's also really wasteful.Our server was incredibly nice, though she did mess up my order, bringing me the full plate when I'd only ordered individual pieces.  When the bill came, it wasn't adjusted to reflect what I'd ordered.  I came here on the fourth day they were open, so maybe they haven't worked out the kinks yet.  Our server also hovered three feet from the table while I was signing my receipt and deciding on the tip, which was awkward.My favorite part was the music.  Ray Charles.  BB King.  Stevie Ray Vaughn.  Eric Clapton.  Great playlist.The place is very big with high ceilings and two TVs at the bar.  It looked like the kind of place where you'd order at a front counter, but they seat and serve you.  There's no host stand, which seems like an oversight, considering the layout.Gus's is an okay restaurant, and maybe the food will improve in time, but I'm not sure I'd go back.

28.description: Great fried chicken. Skip the sides because those are terrible!

45.description: Great fried chicken and great service.  Fried chicken was very crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.   The batter they use does have a spicy kick to it which was a nice surprise.Our waiter (Joseph I believe) was very attentive and explained the menu very well for my first time dining there.  Would recommend and can't wait to go back for fried chicken fix.

33.description: I grew up an hour from Memphis, but Gus and I didn't have the chance to meet until we both ended up in Chicago. And boy, I'm so glad we did.This is, without a doubt, the best fried chicken in Chicago. Unlike so many others that are thickly battered, greasy, and fatty, Gus's fried chicken is light, crisp, flavorful, and moist.No gross, flubby skin sloughing off the chicken here, folks!I also love the atmosphere, which is casual but fun. Wide open. Clean. Not greasy and grimy like you might expect of a fried chicken joint.The okra and fried green tomatoes were both good--but not fantastic. They need some kind of sauce aside from the bottled ranch, which wasn't so tasty. Wish they made some homemade sauce!The chicken dinner, though, was FANTASTIC. Even my wife, who doesn't love fried chicken as much as I do, was impressed.It's flavorful--must be brined. And spicy! And served with white bread, just like any good fried chicken should be.I wasn't expecting much off the sides, as most Yelp-ers seem to think they are lackluster, but we had the baked beans, the coleslaw, and the mac and cheese and thought all were really, really good.They also have sweet tea, which any self-respecting southern restaurant should have!It's bit pricey, is the only drawback. We paid like $55 for lunch for two. I definitely don't remember paying that at the fried chicken shops back home, but I'd pay it again cause, well, it was damn good!

43.description: Located in the west loop Fulton Market.Free street parking.I love fried chicken but I tend to stay away from it to somewhat try to be healthy if you know what I mean. When I saw that Gus's was opening near us I knew I had to give a try. We got the 8 piece dark special, large greens, medium mac and cheese and fried pickles. Like, how is the skin of the chicken so crispy and the meat is so tender?? And the skin had some heat to it which made it even better. We decided the chicken is worth returning for but the sides? eh.

2.description: For those that have read my reviews or know me, I am in love with fried chicken, especially with waffles.  I stumbled upon this place in the Fulton district last week, after an interview, and I said to myself..."self, you need some quality fried chicken for lunch", and this place looks like it was meant for me, the whole, right place at the right time saying.  I was NOT disappointed.  My server, Joseph, is now my new best friend when I come back here.  He was as pleasant as could be, introducing himself and being informative and just really making me feel like I was at home.  He notes that I should feel free to yell for him or scream at him if I need.  haha  He assures me that there are no heat lamps keeping the chicken suntanned in the back, that everything is very fresh and hot, but takes a little time.  He does note that the chicken is spicy, and I prefer a little spice, but not overwhelmingly.  Offers me gallons of water and a fire extinguisher if need be.  The chicken has a bit of heat in the skin, but nothing that makes me sweat thankfully.  It hits you a little on the back end, but I was really tearing into this chicken.  I don't love the styrofoam plate is comes on, a doubled paper plate would have sufficed.  I'm not a fan of non recyclable products.  The chicken is so juicy, and the outside has a great crunchy texture.  It is served ontop of a piece of white bread that baffles me.  No reason for it to be there.  Joseph gives me a little bottle of clover honey after I notice that my nose is drippy (the heat haha).  The honey mutes the heat.  The beans are tasty, but a little too ketchup (is that was I'm tasting?)  The coleslaw is good, nice and creamy, but a little liquidy on the bottom.  I ordered a small side of the mac n cheese.  The temperature is great, it's creamy and good flavor, a little too spicy on the top.The service was simply amazing, I double tipped.  The chicken was just so good, and different.  The sides were good enough, but the mac n cheese outshines the slaw and the beans.  I'll definitely be back though.

18.description: Just a bit spicy, crispy and fried up to order, Gus's is the new place in Chicago to sample us some Tennessee-an fried chicken. On a frigid day, I wouldn't be hesistant to take a piece and hold my hands over the top to warm up. Oh, my little tasty poultry hand warmer.You can order by the piece, plate or bucket. We got ourselves a plate which normally is a choice of 2 or 3 pieces along with 2 sides and bread. The staple side of sweet baked beans and creamy slaw complements perfectly with the spicy chicken. I also got to take a bite of greens (slightly spicy) and okra (wished they weren't cut and fried into tiny little pieces, lost the slime factor), The dark cuts of thigh and leg are satisfying, but opting for white cuts, in particular, the breast, is huge! I got to try all 3 and they are juicy, spicy and crispy. If you like fried chicken, you need to add this to your list. There ain't nothing like southern fried chicken, they know how to fry.

41.description: WOW! if you ever need a fried chicken fix, this is your place. I absolutely do not like "restaurant" fried chicken but I have since been swayed after eating here. We started with the fired green tomatoes - mouth watering! The ordered the 8 piece dark with greens, potato salad and mac and cheese. Sides were mediocre, but who cared since the chicken was so great. Forget, Harold's, KFC, and  Popeyes, Gus has them all beat by a long shot! Service was good, although our server was a little too accommodating. A definite favorite of mine.

52.description: Great chicken for a great price! Be sure to check this place out if you find yourself in the Fullton Market area. The waitstaff is very friendly and their spicy take on Southern flavors is welcomed amidst Chicago's other eats. The fried chicken by itself is already very flavorful - they marinate it in something similar to Frank's Hot Red before frying so be careful if you are not a fan of spicy food. The environment is very casual and great for larger groups. Be sure to take advantage of their meal deals and add appropriate sides to accompany your meal.

50.description: New favorite fried chicken place in Chicago!  The chicken is perfect, crispy, and skin has a bit of a kick.  Chill atmosphere with a good draft selection.  Went on a sunday night with no wait, but I can definitely seeing this place getting packed in the spring/summer time.If you get sweet tea, they have unlimited refills.. I realize this is probably standard for chicken places, but just not used to that much here in Chicago anymore.   The sides here are the best sides I've had in a really long time.  Not a usual fan of the slaw, but it was delicious here.  Price is good for being in the West Loop and compared to some other chicken places in Chicago.Can't wait to go back!

4.description: Overall I'd give it 3.5 stars, as the chicken really was the star and was juicy, flavorful and well seasoned. However, none of the sides blew me away and for the price... I guess it just wasn't worth it to me to want to return again.Pros:- all of the food came out piping hot!- the dark chicken (leg and thigh) was very juicy- chicken skin was super crispy and had kick in the seasoningCons:- mac n cheese was bland and uneventful- fried okra was also bland, it would have been great if they put some kick in the breading but tasted like frozen ones from the supermarket :(- cole slaw and beans were good... but similar to KFC good- fried green tomatoes were mushy on the inside and while the breading was very crispy, it was bland and could use some zest/kick in the seasoning. The ranch dipping sauce could have been elevated into a garlic aioli or something of that sort...also for $6.95 you only get 6 small pieces.Lots of seating and quick, friendly service. But so much more potential that is just not being met. For $45 for 2 people, you can do better with fried chicken in Chicago.

6.description: Soooo, the chicken doesn't disappoint, it's delicious. I grew up outside of Memphis, TN and visited the original Gus's Chicken in Mason, TN several times. I also visited the 2nd location in downtown Memphis a few times. The Chicago Gus's is true to the original, from the chicken recipe to the atmosphere. However, I do appreciate the cleanliness/atmosphere of the Chicago restaurant. It's true to the original Gus's "vibe", but much more inviting if you want to eat in.I have to admit, the lackluster customer service made my experience start off on a slightly sour note. I called in my order,with an expectation to not have to wait when I picked it up. I arrived 20 minutes later and still had to wait 15 minutes for them to prepare my order???? Soooo, what's the point of taking phone orders?? The place had just opened and there was 1 couple eating in when I arrived, so the restaurant wasn't busy. No explanation or apology was given, the cashier just let me wait, then handed me my food.

22.description: Lol how is this place world famous?I mean the name is a total send off. The only thing they offer to the world is an incredible amount of pollution. CAUTION: ALL FOOD HERE IS SERVED ON STYROFOAM I'm baffled that I had a $50 meal served to me completely on disposables. How is this even legal? In a time where Chicago is banning the use of plastic bags, Gus's opens and practically defeats any progress we've made thus far.anyways, the chicken was alright. Both employees I talked to warned me about the chicken being very spicy - I felt totally lied to.  The chicken has little to no spice at all.  The baked beans served on the side were alright, but the coleslaw tasted fresh out of a can. Lol, not trying to diss this place too bad, but it was really mediocre. They need to step their sides up, they couldn't be any more basic. Parson's fried chicken in Logan is farrrrrrr better than Gus's. Hands down.

15.description: I admit, I was skeptical. After that terrible trash of Honey Butter Fried Chicken I didn't trust any chicago institution to deliver on fried chicken. But Gus's is from Memphis! If there is one thing you can be guaranteed is that hipsters haven't swarmed the southern city(yet) and pathetically appropriated their laid back and humbled cuisine.Went on a Friday night and although there were quite a few diners it didn't prevent us from grabbing a spot. Ordered 3 piece dark with fries and M&C as the side. Now every one who has ever had my fried chicken say it's probably the best they ever had. I am ashamed to say I would gladly take Gus's over mine ANY day. This shit was juicy, salty, had a nice spicy kick without being too spicy where it impedes in stuffing your face. The crust was thin and crackling. There is not a single thing I can complain about regarding the chicken.Even the sides had a level of execution that could only come from a true passion in the cuisine and process. The mac and cheese had noodles that were still toothsome, fries hand cut and fluffy, greens tender and flavorful. Compare this to a hipster hellhole like HBFC where they distinguish their food through gimmicks and naming it a particular way. You don't need honey butter on chicken that already has tremendous flavor. You don't need pimento in your M&C if the cheese flavor comes through.I wish there was a little more value built into the food, but it's to be expected for the area. Truth be told I'd imagine this establishment being more fitting in another area, but regardless I'd recommend anyone go to Gus's and see how food is supposed to be executed.

57.description: Having been to the one in Memphis and liked it, we tried this one in Chicago a few weeks ago.  From an atmosphere standpoint, it's like night and day.  The Memphis one is not in the greatest of areas and if memory serves correctly, a little divey.  The one in Chicago is the complete opposite - more lofty/trendy like and much more airy feeling.We started with the fried pickles and even though they came out after we got our meal (which I hate! - but our waitress did apologize twice about it), they were delicious.  Wonderfully cooked - lightly breaded - and a really pickle slice inside.  I would definitely get this again.We got several of their wings / breasts / thighs and everything was very tasty.  I actually liked it better here than the Memphis - whereas, my husband thought the Memphis place was better tasting.  It had a wonderful crisp on the skin and was nice and hot (temperature and spice level).  I did ask if they do a less spicy rendition (for people like my parents who like food bland), and they unfortunately do not.  I wish they did b/c I would bring my parents here.We also got the cole slaw and mac and cheese - which contrary to what others are saying, i thought were fine.  Nothing fabulous, but I would order both again.They do have a bar here, but since it was lunch, we did not order anything.  Overall - a good place and definitely one I would be back to.

20.description: Gus's is no frill and finger lickin' good. A friend recommended we try this place since it just opened. When I walked inside it was not at all what I expected for the trendy West Loop/Fulton Market area. But it's a nice change. They have a variety of cheap beer and some specialty cocktails, which made everyone happy. I got the individual breast and the mac and cheese. I wasn't sure if it would be enough but it was a LOT of food. The chicken just melts in your mouth. Its crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside, exactly what fried chicken should be. Be aware that this chicken is spicy. It's not going to burn a hole in your mouth but it's definitely a slow burn that builds up as you eat--it's delicious! Others in my party had the dark meat, which they argued was even better than the white. I could come back here again and again and not get sick of this chicken. The mac and cheese was good, but basic. I kind of felt this way about all of the sides. We also had the fried pickles, which were spears instead of chips (my preference). They were hot and crispy and the batter stayed on the pickle which I think is hard to find. Our server was also really friendly and laid back, which made the experience all the more enjoyable.

36.description: I had real high expectations for this place on this sub-zero Chicago day.  The service was good and the ambience as well.  The chicken was full of flavor, however, the batter was chewy rather than crispy.  Was it intended to be that way or did I go on a bad day?  I'm sure if I will give this place another try or not.  At this point I prefer Parson's in Logan Square for my fried chicken fix!

14.description: Being located in Fulton market it is pretty tough to find parking but this time I got lucky and parked right in front.  So I went here during lunch time so It was pretty busy and not knowing how it worked to order me and my friend were instructed to sit down and would be served.  We sat there for about 10 mins without any assistance and customers that sat down later than us got assisted before us.  We finally got noticed and the server that helped was extremely nice and apologized for the inconvenience.  They covered our fried pickles which we had for appetizers.  They were good and were in spear form rather than slices how I've had them at other places.  I ordered 3 piece dark with mac and cheese and slaw.  Everything was really fresh and tasty. Will go back again and will try the white meat and alternative sides.

58.description: Great noodles! The best Reman I have ate in Chicago. Modern environment. Nice service. But not easy to find parking place.

56.description: After sleeping on writing this review, I decided I still wanted to write it because of the unpleasant service we experienced coming here. I should clarify this is because of what happened with the hostess, not the assistant manager or other service, and that the food is probably about 4.5 stars if I rated that separately. I usually dont like to be unpleasant for fear of getting spit in my food but this one bothered me a lot.TL;DR food good, waiting experience badWe put our names down on the waitling list for 4 for dinner (no reservations) and was told the wait would be about 30 minutes. We also had to wait outside because it's a small place and was told it was a fire code violation. That is fine no problem, mind you it is the first day that it started snowing. When we were walking outside we see a few other couples come in and a family of 4 and also put their names on the waiting list. While we were waiting outside in the cold, we see that the family gets to wait inside for 20 minutes. That is annoying since it is a fire code but understandable because they have 2 kids, whatever this is no problem. We decide to stand closer to the door and begin to walk inside, the hostess begins to seat the family of four, and this is where we are like what the heck. We were definitely here before the family and we have the same party size so I ask the hostess what's going on. She tells me, oh yea oops, we have space over there at the community table if you want.What the heck, first of all, you didn't tell us our table was ready. Second of all this family has been given a standalone table which would have been nice for us. No one came out to tell us even though we were standing outside for 20 minutes and what the freak is the point of your waiting list if you're not going to use it. And then when I was trying to ask her for her name for this review, she told me i was threatening her so I was like wtf and we walked to our seats at the community table. Later while we were sitting at the community table, the assistant manager came to apologize and was very nice and I appreciate that which redeemed some of the night. But I wish the hostess had owned up to her mistake, but she was just so dodgy, even trying to put the blame on us for either not having a complete party even though she was the one who didn't even bother to check on us or let us know. I wish I could get her name but I know they were trying to protect her from this rage review. she had short hair and looked young and probably never had to be an adult before.Food:we had brussel sprouts and fried chicken appetizers. A little salty but who knew I could like brussel sproutsTakoyaki octopus balls were good, a little soft but each place makes it differently so nothing wrong here.Shrimp and Fried chicken buns, Shrimp was amazing can't go wrong with this, I didn't get to try the chicken.Ramen was good, we had spicy chicken something and oshioka something but they were both really good. I really really love the soft boiled egg, my girlfriends spicy chicken ramen was missing the egg but whatever I was tired of starting shit. The egg is probably the trademark of this place if I were to coin it. The pork belly I got was also not all fat and was delicious.Green tea mochi and Black sesame mochi were both amazing treats.This ramen place is a much needed improvement over all the other ramen places in the chicago area. The bowls are not all broth and come with a good amount of everything. Unlike other ramen places that give u salty salty broth, this one was a nice change

29.description: The perfect remedy to a cold winter's day in Chicago, Ramen Takeya was a fantastic place to stop for a quick lunch.We were warmly welcomed by the person working at the bar, and we were seated and given menus promptly. Both my roommate and I decided to order the Chicken Paitan, since it was so popular with other Yelp reviews. IT WAS AMAZING. The broth, pork belly char siu, and the noodles were all cooked to perfection, and they gave very generous portions of bamboo shoots (also delicious.) The bowls are deceptive in that it looks like there isn't much in them, but they hold a surprisingly large amount of food (which was awesome). Ultimately, we had a wonderful experience at Ramen Takeya; I usually feel disgustingly full after ramen, but Ramen Takeya was just right and warmed me up for the rest of the day. I can't wait to go back and try everything else!

42.description: In my opinion, this is the best ramen joint in Chicago.  I know, bold bold statement, but I think Ramen Takeya earns it.  Let's get right to food, because damn it, that's what matters.  All the ramens are great but the chicken paitan is freakin special (try the chicken paitan with chicken rather than pork belly).  The broth is incredibly silky, structured, and just down-right amazing.  I don't think you'll find a better broth in Chicago.  Some folks like their ramen spicy but others don't so don't feel shy about asking for additional spicy on the side (add to taste).  The noodles are also absolutely amazing and really strike that balance of dense and soft while retaining just the right amount of bite.  Again, I can't identify a better noodle in Chicago.Beyond the ramen, Takeya kills it.  Try the buns, the small rice bowls!  All are fantastic which makes it tough to choose.  I could go on and on but just try them.  You will love them! The atmosphere is cozy and comfortable.  I love the music at Furious Spoon but Ramen Takeya doesn't have that vibe.  The ramen does the talking at Takeya.  Service has always been great but most ramen joints in town have solid service.Bottom line, Takeya has its priorities right.  Awesome broth and noodles before all else.  If you like good ramen or are trying to find the best in the city, drop what you are doing right now and head over to Ramen Takeya.  Heck, you might see me there.

23.description: I seriously love this ramen shop. so cute with an amazing full bar (no hot sake though but we will forgive that). I ordered the spicy paitan ramen, kurobuta pork gyozas, a foamy headed super dry asahi, and a spicy miso. the gyozas had the cornstarch skirt and were delicious, though a tad too salty for my taste. the dipping sauce had no vinegar/acidic element. no vinegar on the table. the spicy paitan was a tad too salty but didn't stop me from devouring the whole damn thing. the standouts were the amazingly tender and very flavorful pork belly which was further complemented by the menma and green onions. there were also bits of regular diced onion, which was something I've never experienced before but was not opposed to. appreciated the texture and bite. the perfectly done ajitsuke tamago added to the amazingly sticky yet clean tasting broth. decidedly outstanding. will return.

47.description: Ramen Takeya is actually the first place I ever tried ramen, and truly has ruined ramen for me at any other place. It's a small space, but the food is well worth it. I personally had the chicken paitan, which I loved and continue to go back for. Ramen Takeya also has a liquor license and serves cocktails, sake, and beer. Overall, great food and cool atmosphere.

8.description: Restaurant is located in Fulton Market District. It's a very small ramen shop with an intimate setting. We had the pork buns, spicy miso ramen, and Osaka shio ramen. Both ramen's broth were delicious and flavorful. The spicy miso ramen had a good miso flavor and a nice kick (it wasn't overly spicy). The Osaka shio ramen's broth had a very clean and flavorful taste. The pork buns melt-in-your-mouth and had a good sauce that accompanied it. Verdict: I would definitely go back and possibly try one of the chicken broth ramen's and the takoyaki!

31.description: I've been here a number of times and it's become my ramen place of choice. It's close to home, but more importantly, they always have a table available and service and food are reliable and consistent.The place is relatively small but they have a variety of table sizes (communal and individual) as well as a ramen bar where you can watch the chefs prepare the soup bowls. Staff is prompt, and food comes out quickly. The menu has a few different broths to select from. I opt for the shoyu ramen. Their broths are different than the typical tonkatsu ramen at some of the other Chicago staples like Wasabi. It's a little lighter-- not as rich or nearly as thick/creamy. It actually reminds me a bit of an Asian chicken noodle soup which is awesome. They also have really delicious buns here-- special shoutout to the fried chicken karaage bun. And finally, they  make a mean cocktail. My only negative is that I wish they would add a tonkatsu broth to the menu. Their sister restaurant is Wasabi, afterall! If you're looking for a more casual / inexpensive option in the West Loop that can serve you quickly without the 2 hour wait, try out Ramen Takeya!

34.description: A wonderful little ramen spot in the west loop! I went with a friend on a Thursday evening at around 5:15 pm and we were one of the first ones there. The tables are a little tight, but not uncomfortably so. We both ordered the Spicy Chicken Paitan. The noodles were good, but what really stood out to me was the chicken broth. A lot of ramen places tend to over salt the broth, but Ramen Takeya gets it right- not too salty and very flavorful. The chili hits you right in the back of the throat and provides just the right amount of kick. Bamboo shoots were tender and loved the soft boiled egg. I personally thought the bowls were big enough and filling enough on their own but I'm looking forward to coming back and trying some appetizers. Servers were very helpful with suggestions and ambiance was nice!

16.description: Our meal could be summed up in five words: Overly loud music, bad soup.We went here for lunch today and it just wasn't good. This was our third (and last visit) to Ramen Takeya. The portions of pork in the ramen appear to have shrunk in size by about half, and what little you do get is mostly fat. We ate about a 1/3 of it because who wants a big bite of fat? The bamboo was undercooked or cut too thick. Either way, it had an off-putting texture. And, as icing on the cake, after we ordered our food, they started blaring their music. I don't know about you, but I like to be able to hear the people I dine with. It was too much.

13.description: Yummy, yummy ramen! I came with two other people for a weekday lunch date, it took about 5-10 minutes to get seated, which was surprising to me seeing how small the restaurant is. It's a cozy restaurant with a nice modern decor. It didn't feel cramped at all. It was very comfortable at the bar and the service was quick! I ordered the Spicy Chicken Paitan Ramen, which was really flavorful with strong chicken flavors coming across in the broth. I was slightly disappointed with the spice level (or lack there of). I really wished it was significantly spicer,  but that's just personal preference. I'll probably give the Miso Bold & Spicy a try next time! They do serve beer and alcohol for those of you into the boozy lunches! Great ramen option, but to be honest I prefer Yusho and Urban Belly's ramens (once again just personal preferences). P.S. Parking is a nightmare over here, find another way to travel here!

11.description: I've been here a number of times and it's become my ramen place of choice. It's close to home, but more importantly, they always have a table available and service and food are reliable and consistent.The place is relatively small but they have a variety of table sizes (communal and individual) as well as a ramen bar where you can watch the chefs prepare the soup bowls. Staff is prompt, and food comes out quickly. The menu has a few different broths to select from. I opt for the shoyu ramen. Their broths are different than the typical tonkatsu ramen at some of the other Chicago staples like Wasabi. It's a little lighter-- not as rich or nearly as thick/creamy. It actually reminds me a bit of an Asian chicken noodle soup which is awesome. They also have really delicious buns here-- special shoutout to the fried chicken karaage bun. And finally, they  make a mean cocktail. My only negative is that I wish they would add a tonkatsu broth to the menu. Their sister restaurant is Wasabi, afterall! If you're looking for a more casual / inexpensive option in the West Loop that can serve you quickly without the 2 hour wait, try out Ramen Takeya!

39.description: Hands down the best ramen in Chicago. I get the miso bold and spicy and it is perfect each time. The ingredients are fresh, miso broth is loaded with flavor and the right amount of heat, and the pork belly melts in your mouth. Have had many of the appetizers as well and all are great. Definitely a must visit if you're craving ramen!

37.description: Not very flavorful. The most important component to a delicious bowl of ramen from DYI noodles is the soup base. The Tokyo Classic Shoyu was too bland for my liking, and the ingredients seem ordinary.

0.description: Ramen Takeya, I am so thankful for such an amazing meal and dining experience! I honestly couldn't ask for more, my experience was nothing short of perfect! Came in on a Saturday night with my boyfriend and his buddy! His buddy spoke highly of the place and we were instantly hooked on the idea of having a Ramen Night! Thank God it worked out the way it did, I am officially a fan!!!First, the place was packed!!! It was a cold night, perfect for Ramen, so we were prepared to expect the place to be busy. We waited about 20 minutes for a table for 3, Bar Area/Table - we were open to whichever came first! Thankfully, the bar became available first and boy were we lucky! I have to say that the Bar Area is where it is at! Dinner and Entertainment, we had the perfect view of the restaurants inner workings and it was soooo cool! Watching the cooks prepare the food was sooooo amazing, it made it harder to decide on what to eat oh and it made my hunger pains worse in all the right ways!!! Obviously, we came in for the Ramen, I went with the Vegan Ramen and it was amazing! I have to say, being a strict vegetarian with a list of food restrictions, it's nice to find a restaurant that satisfies my search for good eats!!! On top of my ramen I ordered, and totally recommend, the Brussel Sprouts and a side of rice... I had to, watching these cooks got my tummy begging for more food! That alone was amazing, I'd be satisfied with a couple of those orders alone, YUM!I cannot begin to express how delicious every bite was! I've had my share of Vegetarian/Vegan Ramen and have always felt cheated, Takeya knows they got it down perfect! I decided not to add anything to my ramen, other than chili oil, I wanted to taste it for what it was and now I know how I'll be ordering this dish in the near future! Needless to say, the guys loved everything, they definitely got up satisfied and happy!I should also mention that the service was amazing! Even with sitting at the bar, our server was very attentive and checked on us routinely throughout the night. I could not ask him for more, thank you for an amazing experience!I am definitely adding this place to my list of recommendations and will obviously be back for more!

38.description: Certainly a refreshing take to see that Chicago can welcome a ramen joint that specializes in chicken broth. It's a great addition to the Futon Market situated among other winners like Cemitas Puebla, Glazed and Infused, and Publican. The space is dimly lit and somewhat limited...it was smaller than Wasabi I think. Luckily, there wasn't a crowd on the Saturday after Xmas.    We ordered the Chicken Paitan of course since it has the basic focal point of a chicken broth. Initially, I felt like it was a bowl of "souped" up chicken noodle soup with a super rich chicken broth, with lots of straight egg noodles and amped up ingredients for add-ins...and maybe that's what it is in many ways. We enjoyed it. This was a great compliment to the Miso Bold and Spicy ramen. We were warned before ordering since it also showed 4 little chilli peppers to indicate that it was spicy. Though it's not numbingly spicy, it has a great kick and I liked that it had a lot of bean sprouts. Both bowls had a good amount of toppings and weren't too salty. The pork char sui didn't stand standout and the noodles were okay (they were straight in these bowls).     We also ordered the crispy takoyaki, which was too doughy, and there was too much sweet bbq sauce on it.  Overall it's more likes a 3.5. It's a welcome addition to the ramen scene and great for the current price point.

51.description: Came here on a weeknight with a friend. We didn't have to wait at all and were immediately seated. Place is small, hidden amongst many many amazing places in the West loop! The inside is very cozy and casual with mostly shared seating. We ordered the brussle sprouts, spicy chicken paitan and Miso bold and spicy! We ordered wine and OMG the price tag on one small glass of regular wine (14 for a glass seemed a bit unreasonable!)!!! Anyways, the Brussels sprouts stole the night! They were so delicious! Crispy, sour-ish, with a little kick to it, I can remember the taste while writing this! Both the ramen were incredible as well! Super delicious! We chugged down our bowls and were immensely full! The service was on point as well! Definitely a place worth going to for the ramen fix!

27.description: If you visit you must order the Brussels sprouts... 10/10! The space is pretty small so if you have a large party I would definitely make a reservation. The ramen is fantastic. I had the chicken paitan ramen bowl. I substituted the Berkshire pork belly char siu for chicken char siu and I did not regret it. The bowl had so much flavor and was VERY filling. The music was a bit loud, but overall I had a positive experience. I would definitely done here again  and encourage any ramen lovers to come check it out!

32.description: We stumbled upon this place during a random night out and this place has a great atmosphere (and decor), the staff was pretty nice too and they actually had vegetarian options with fake meat. Totally a win. It was all very delicious and it totally got me hooked on ramen. It's not quite High Five Ramen, but I would definitely got back again.

54.description: The bowl of Chicken Paitan I got had MSG in it. I can't imagine why a place that otherwise seems to make its broth with pride would do that. It's hours later, and my entire palate is still completely shot. It may not be a deal-breaker for others, but it certainly is for me. Why are you making me go to the douchier Furious Spoon?

48.description: Well-deserved five stars.  I'll try to be complete about our visit this past weekend.Saturday ~7:30/8pm, table for two.  Finding parking was a bit of a pain, but luckily we were seated immediately (at a table, not the bar).  The place was crowded and people were really packed in there - seems like a standard format for ramen places these days.  Lots of good signs here: 1) promising yelp reviews, 2) super crowded, people standing around outside, 3) and it smell of broth fills your nose as soon as you walk in.  We started off with takoyaki since my girlfriend had never tried them before - they were kind of different from how I remember them, batter-wise.  Nonetheless, they were flavorful with chunks of octopus and coated with dancing bonito flakes, but they were a bit heavy with a tonkatsu-like sauce and mayonnaise.For the ramen, I had the chicken paitan and my girlfriend had the osaka shio.  The broth was fantastic - the kind you want to keep drinking as you slurp down noodles, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and green onions.  The noodles had a decent amount of bite to them and the cha shiu was buttery-tender and retained its sweet barbecue flavor.  Of all the things in the bowl, perhaps the only thing I wish had been different was the egg - it was cooked well, but was plain.  We meant business so we wrapped this meal up in about 40 minutes, tops. We don't mess around, and apparently Ramen Takeya doesn't, either!  Would gladly return and sample other starters next time, appetites willing.

44.description: FIVE STAR RAMEN.Finally we got a great ramen place in the city that doesn't require 1-2 hours of drive to Misoya in Mount Prospect or Santouka in Arlington Heights. The noodles are delicious and the broth (despite the fact that it's chicken-based) is very tasty. The spicy chicken paitan is not too spicy; I just wished it came with more than two small chunks of pork. During cold Chicago days, I opted for miso bold and spicy ramen with pork. In the future, I would ask for less bean sprouts since the bean sprouts dominated 50% of the bowl space and it's a total distraction/waste.In the end, I think Ramen Takeya is a strong four star as compared to other sad places like Ramen-san or God forbids the awful Strings Ramen in Chinatown. Also, if your pocket is thick, get the uni and tuna mini rice bowl. They are heavenly but costs an arm and a leg.

24.description: Good: - Cool little room, reminiscent of actual dives in Japan.- Super-friendly bartender (we ate at the bar).- No wait for a table or bar seat at 6:30pm on a Saturday.- Groovy 80s music- Gyoza are creatively served and delish.- Ramen was reasonably tasty.Not so good:- Salt, salt, salt, salt. Yes, ramen is salty. But EVERYTHING here is salty, in a way you don't realize until the next morning when you feel simultaneously dehydrated and bloated like 10 gallons of sea water in a 5 gallon bag.- Fried chicken: tasty, sure.  But not worth the grease/salt tradeoff IMO.- Uni/toro: the unii was super-fresh, but the rest of it was just unimpressive. Toro was barely noticeable other than the fishiness.- Bold and spicy ramen: don't get me wrong, we ate the whole thing. It tasted good. But it wasn't outstanding...broth didn't have the body of authentic (and unhealthy) ramen broth, fatty pork belly instead of cheek, noodles were fine but not great.- Expensive for what it is.That is all.

7.description: I seriously love this ramen shop. so cute with an amazing full bar (no hot sake though but we will forgive that). I ordered the spicy paitan ramen, kurobuta pork gyozas, a foamy headed super dry asahi, and a spicy miso. the gyozas had the cornstarch skirt and were delicious, though a tad too salty for my taste. the dipping sauce had no vinegar/acidic element. no vinegar on the table. the spicy paitan was a tad too salty but didn't stop me from devouring the whole damn thing. the standouts were the amazingly tender and very flavorful pork belly which was further complemented by the menma and green onions. there were also bits of regular diced onion, which was something I've never experienced before but was not opposed to. appreciated the texture and bite. the perfectly done ajitsuke tamago added to the amazingly sticky yet clean tasting broth. decidedly outstanding. will return.

49.description: I must have a parasite in my stomach cause I devoured a bowl of noodles and felt nothing. The egg is delicious and I enjoyed how jelly it is. That's skill. Broth is clean, noodles should be eaten hot. There's a good variety of broth, I typically prefer pork over chicken. I was recommended to try Tokyo Shio, it's good.  Now I wanna try all of them!

40.description: Pretty good ramen.Prices were decent.Not a bad wait either.

53.description: One of the better of the ramen joints with an urban Tokyo feel.   Broths are on the lighter side; no tonkotsu.

30.description: Love these hanging light bulbs at the bar, create some type of illusion, I can't stop staring at them.Had Ebi buns (sweet chili shrimp buns), were really good, love the soft fluffy buns.I had a vegetarian buckwheat noodle bowl, best one I ever had in the states! Really good broth, lots mushrooms in my bowl, great for this winter weather!

46.description: Was very happily surprised by this place!!Came in for an early dinner around 5:45 on a Friday. Ordered the vegan ramen with egg noodles and added an egg. Wow!!!Vegetarian Asian foods are usually very bland but the vegan ramen was packed with flavor - delectable flavor. Portions were generous, too. I wish my stomach was bigger so I could have enjoyed every last bite rather than leaving the last eighth of my dishI've also had the vegan ramen at Ramensan and I have to say I prefer it there more. I think it's bc the ramen is sweeter at Ramensan which is more of my taste. Doesn't mean that Ramen Tayeka isn't amazingly delicious!One more thing - no hot sake served here..only cold.Will definitely be returning!

1.description: I like Ramen and I get craving for it. This visit was to quench one those cravings. First of all the plus points. Welcoming staff, great ambiance and the cool music. We were seated right beside kitchen, separating us by a glass. So we even got a great view. I ordered to the Tokyo Shoyu Ramen. The Ramen was mediocre at its best. The broth was slightly clearer than what it should have been. The only flavour I could taste was salt. Come on guys, where is the porky flavour I was looking for. The noddles themselves are OK. Slightly underdone. And the portion was extremely small for, what I have paid. If you have craving for Ramen and you don't mind mediocrity, then this the place to be.

55.description: Got the buns and the eel dish as appetizers as well as the classic shoyu ramen. This was enough to eat for the two of us! The eel dish as an appetizer was especially tasty. Quick service---walked in and didn't have to wait though most other tables were full .Casual dress.

9.description: I have been wanting to try this place for a while. I was not disappointed. I had the Tokyo classic and thought it was a perfect blend of spicy and bold. The flavors were perfect.  The waiter rated this as a 4/10 spice level. I was considering the miso bold and spicy ramen but he said that ons is closer to a 8/10 for spice level.  I thought I can easily do the spicy one but the waiter suggested I try the Tokyo classic. I am glad I did as I would have probably been dying if I had the other one.  I regularly go to Strings, but I liked this ramen more so this will now be my go to place.

26.description: This is with out a doubt one of the worst places I've ever been served a meal. I ordered a spicy miso ramen which can barely be called spicy.The ramen was ok at best. We came in well before closing and the manager actually had the balls to kick us out because they were "closed". I've never once in years of Chicago dining been asked to leave a restaurant. I've never been so disrespected in my life.

25.description: Not much meat in the ramen--mostly noodles and vegetables. Tasted great, though.

12.description: FIVE STAR RAMEN.Finally we got a great ramen place in the city that doesn't require 1-2 hours of drive to Misoya in Mount Prospect or Santouka in Arlington Heights. The noodles are delicious and the broth (despite the fact that it's chicken-based) is very tasty. The spicy chicken paitan is not too spicy; I just wished it came with more than two small chunks of pork. During cold Chicago days, I opted for miso bold and spicy ramen with pork. In the future, I would ask for less bean sprouts since the bean sprouts dominated 50% of the bowl space and it's a total distraction/waste.In the end, I think Ramen Takeya is a strong four star as compared to other sad places like Ramen-san or God forbids the awful Strings Ramen in Chinatown. Also, if your pocket is thick, get the uni and tuna mini rice bowl. They are heavenly but costs an arm and a leg.

59.description: Walked over here due to super long wait at High Five Ramen, which we expected, but didn't want to wait for. Takeya was delicious and authentic and I don't understand why there weren't more people there. The place is small and it was almost full, but I couldn't believe there was no wait. Not that I am complaining since I was so hungry!My colleague and I sat at the bar.  A bit tight on the elbow room but didn't put a damper on anything. Love the short and precise menu, though I wish they had a seafood option. Bartender looks like a young Anthony Hopkins btw  and he was very nice and attentive!Will definitely be back again!

21.description: Beautiful, tasty & nice atmosphere. I entered just as they opened, 20 minutes later & the place is buzzing. No wonder when the food is this good.Looking around other diners are having similar deliciousness dropped to them! Will definitely be a regular here.

17.description: The perfect remedy to a cold winter's day in Chicago, Ramen Takeya was a fantastic place to stop for a quick lunch.We were warmly welcomed by the person working at the bar, and we were seated and given menus promptly. Both my roommate and I decided to order the Chicken Paitan, since it was so popular with other Yelp reviews. IT WAS AMAZING. The broth, pork belly char siu, and the noodles were all cooked to perfection, and they gave very generous portions of bamboo shoots (also delicious.) The bowls are deceptive in that it looks like there isn't much in them, but they hold a surprisingly large amount of food (which was awesome). Ultimately, we had a wonderful experience at Ramen Takeya; I usually feel disgustingly full after ramen, but Ramen Takeya was just right and warmed me up for the rest of the day. I can't wait to go back and try everything else!

10.description: As the sister restaurant to Wasabi, my favorite ramen joint, Takeya is bound to be amazing-- and it is! I love the decor and service here, though it seems like there isn't as much seating here so I would avoid going with big groups. I love that the soup/broth focuses on chicken here, though the ramen I had definitely had a Japanese-inspired chicken noodle soup vibe going on. It was good, but I think I prefer pork-based broths more. I do wish they allow substitutions here- I was told I couldn't substitute spinach for the bamboo shoots and would have to pay extra for the spinach, even though the bamboo shoots are more expensive on the menu. That's really my only complaint! Another great ramen place to add to my rotation!

5.description: A wonderful little ramen spot in the west loop! I went with a friend on a Thursday evening at around 5:15 pm and we were one of the first ones there. The tables are a little tight, but not uncomfortably so. We both ordered the Spicy Chicken Paitan. The noodles were good, but what really stood out to me was the chicken broth. A lot of ramen places tend to over salt the broth, but Ramen Takeya gets it right- not too salty and very flavorful. The chili hits you right in the back of the throat and provides just the right amount of kick. Bamboo shoots were tender and loved the soft boiled egg. I personally thought the bowls were big enough and filling enough on their own but I'm looking forward to coming back and trying some appetizers. Servers were very helpful with suggestions and ambiance was nice!

3.description: Yum!!! Spicy miso is my favorite here although the chicken Saipan is also very good (broth is super chicken-y!). The noodles are chewy and al debate and hold the broth excellently. It's definitely my go to ramen place in the city even though no Japanese ppl work there lol.

35.description: As the sister restaurant to Wasabi, my favorite ramen joint, Takeya is bound to be amazing-- and it is! I love the decor and service here, though it seems like there isn't as much seating here so I would avoid going with big groups. I love that the soup/broth focuses on chicken here, though the ramen I had definitely had a Japanese-inspired chicken noodle soup vibe going on. It was good, but I think I prefer pork-based broths more. I do wish they allow substitutions here- I was told I couldn't substitute spinach for the bamboo shoots and would have to pay extra for the spinach, even though the bamboo shoots are more expensive on the menu. That's really my only complaint! Another great ramen place to add to my rotation!

19.description: We just moved to Chicago and tonight was our first time at this place. The food was absolutely fantastic! The service and atmosphere were great, too. We will definitely return.

28.description: Just got back from a business lunch at Ramen Takeya, and my tummy is still singing! Legitimately he BEST Brussels sprouts I've ever had!  Furthermore, they have vegetarian ramen, which is delicious.  I already can't wait to go back!

45.description: Ramen - one of my top cravings on a cold Chicago night!Chicken Karaage was our starter for the evening along with an order of Salmon Roe. The Chicken was absolutely delightful! Warm and tender on the inside and crispy on the outside. It came with a mayo type dipping sauce which wasn't too bad. I was hoping it was going to be a curry based mayo sauce. As for the Salmon Roe, it has always been one of our favorites when we're out for ramen.I'm a spicy ramen type of gal so I ordered the Spicy Chicken Paitan - SO very tasty! The main dish came with very tender pork belly pieces and half of an egg. It didn't have much vegetables - sad face. When I go back, I'll need to see if there's a ramen order that has more vegetables.We went on a Friday around 5 or 6PM and there wasn't a wait. The room is dim and intimate, and the server was nice and helpful. We were seated towards the front of the restaurant so I'm not sure how much further the room extended.As for a quick tip on parking, we found free parking less than half a block north of the restaurant. I'm sure there's more in the area, or meter parking as an option. Overall, I would love to go back to try their other dishes!

33.description: They make food extremely slow. Waited for 45 mins for the ramen after being seated. Sighhhh

43.description: Paitan broth was rich and flavorful, the noodles and marinated, soft-boiled egg were good.  Unfortunately, the pork char siu was tough, I didn't want raw chopped onions (the regular type as I'd expect chopped green onions) all over my noodles, rest of garnish was very cold.

2.description: We started with pork belly and spicy chicken buns.  The latter was definitely tastier and I wished i ordered my own.  But can't give it that full 5 starts.  Ever since having the pork belly buns at Ippudo in NYC, there hasn't been a place that beat out that restaurant.  For the main dish, I ordered a spicy chicken paitan which was okay.  It's not bad but not like Ippudo.  I have to say that their noodles were al dente which was nice.  Lastly for dessert we ordered the mochi ice creams.  The green tea mochi tasted nothing like green tea but the black sesame tasted good.  Will definitely go again since I like that fact that they had healthy options.  The food was mostly organic which made me feel I wasn't indulging in anything unhealthy even though I was eating meat.

18.description: Well-deserved five stars.  I'll try to be complete about our visit this past weekend.Saturday ~7:30/8pm, table for two.  Finding parking was a bit of a pain, but luckily we were seated immediately (at a table, not the bar).  The place was crowded and people were really packed in there - seems like a standard format for ramen places these days.  Lots of good signs here: 1) promising yelp reviews, 2) super crowded, people standing around outside, 3) and it smell of broth fills your nose as soon as you walk in.  We started off with takoyaki since my girlfriend had never tried them before - they were kind of different from how I remember them, batter-wise.  Nonetheless, they were flavorful with chunks of octopus and coated with dancing bonito flakes, but they were a bit heavy with a tonkatsu-like sauce and mayonnaise.For the ramen, I had the chicken paitan and my girlfriend had the osaka shio.  The broth was fantastic - the kind you want to keep drinking as you slurp down noodles, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and green onions.  The noodles had a decent amount of bite to them and the cha shiu was buttery-tender and retained its sweet barbecue flavor.  Of all the things in the bowl, perhaps the only thing I wish had been different was the egg - it was cooked well, but was plain.  We meant business so we wrapped this meal up in about 40 minutes, tops. We don't mess around, and apparently Ramen Takeya doesn't, either!  Would gladly return and sample other starters next time, appetites willing.

41.description: My new favorite ramen in Chicago!  Had the spicy chicken paitan and it was awesome, super flavorful broth, jidori egg added great depth and the meat was very tender... Also started with the spicy shrimp app which was good but not worth a repeat visit, unlike the ramen which will have me dropping by often this winter...

52.description: I'm trying to find the best ramen spot in Chicago.  I ordered the miso bold and spicy and it was solid.  Broth was great but the noodles was not quite on par with High Five.  The chicken karaage was not the best I've had.  A tad bit greasy and the outer coating wasn't crispy compared to many other places I've tried.  I would definitely go back for the ramen.  Staff was very helpful and friendly as well.  Those who haven't tried this spot, it's worth going.

50.description: My friend and I had a horrible experience here last night. We called ahead to ask what the wait was and the girl who answered the phone said "20 minutes." Perfect! So, we walked over to the restaurant to put our name in. After giving them our name, they said they would come grab us outside when our table was ready. Outside? I asked if we could wait in the entrance because we were in dresses and it was 20 degrees and they said no, we had to wait outside. Then, I suggested that they take down our number and text or call us when the table was ready and they said they couldn't do that. So just to confirm I explained the situation once again and asked if they were really expecting us to stand out in the dark, in the middle of winter, until they decided to seat us to which they replied "yep." Worst customer service I've experienced in quite awhile- if you can't get seated immediately I would definitely choose another restaurant.

4.description: Love these hanging light bulbs at the bar, create some type of illusion, I can't stop staring at them.Had Ebi buns (sweet chili shrimp buns), were really good, love the soft fluffy buns.I had a vegetarian buckwheat noodle bowl, best one I ever had in the states! Really good broth, lots mushrooms in my bowl, great for this winter weather!

6.description: Certainly a refreshing take to see that Chicago can welcome a ramen joint that specializes in chicken broth. It's a great addition to the Futon Market situated among other winners like Cemitas Puebla, Glazed and Infused, and Publican. The space is dimly lit and somewhat limited...it was smaller than Wasabi I think. Luckily, there wasn't a crowd on the Saturday after Xmas.    We ordered the Chicken Paitan of course since it has the basic focal point of a chicken broth. Initially, I felt like it was a bowl of "souped" up chicken noodle soup with a super rich chicken broth, with lots of straight egg noodles and amped up ingredients for add-ins...and maybe that's what it is in many ways. We enjoyed it. This was a great compliment to the Miso Bold and Spicy ramen. We were warned before ordering since it also showed 4 little chilli peppers to indicate that it was spicy. Though it's not numbingly spicy, it has a great kick and I liked that it had a lot of bean sprouts. Both bowls had a good amount of toppings and weren't too salty. The pork char sui didn't stand standout and the noodles were okay (they were straight in these bowls).     We also ordered the crispy takoyaki, which was too doughy, and there was too much sweet bbq sauce on it.  Overall it's more likes a 3.5. It's a welcome addition to the ramen scene and great for the current price point.

22.description: Loved the Ramen. Happy to finally have a place where the broths are chicken based and light. The seaweed salad was amazing! One of the tastiest salads I have had in a long time!I now need to try their sister restaurant Wasabi - have tried to go there several times but have been discouraged by the constant lines and wait time.

15.description: Was very happily surprised by this place!!Came in for an early dinner around 5:45 on a Friday. Ordered the vegan ramen with egg noodles and added an egg. Wow!!!Vegetarian Asian foods are usually very bland but the vegan ramen was packed with flavor - delectable flavor. Portions were generous, too. I wish my stomach was bigger so I could have enjoyed every last bite rather than leaving the last eighth of my dishI've also had the vegan ramen at Ramensan and I have to say I prefer it there more. I think it's bc the ramen is sweeter at Ramensan which is more of my taste. Doesn't mean that Ramen Tayeka isn't amazingly delicious!One more thing - no hot sake served here..only cold.Will definitely be returning!

57.description: Came here with a large group (10 people) around 8:30/9pm which was probably a mistake, just because most of the tables are smaller. There is a large table for 8 people but we just decided to split up into two groups instead of wait for it. We didn't actually have to wait very long once the entire group arrived, but I guess it was pretty late for dinner. The service is fairly quick. I ordered the spicy chicken paitan, which was really good! I really like that it was chicken based broth, which is pretty different than a lot of the other ramen places in Chicago. The noodles were a good level of chewy and incredibly flavorful. There weren't many vegetables in it or anything but I didn't mind and I guess it allowed me to enjoy the noodles themselves even more. It says it's the 2 chili pepper level of spice, but it wasn't too spicy at all, very reasonable. I also tried the pork belly bun which comes in an order of 2 for $8. Loved the classically soft and fluffy bun and pork belly with the fats, but there was s little too much sauce on one part of the bun and the lettuce and pork weren't evenly placed so at the end I was just eating lettuce and bun, which is a little less than ideal just because I like ending with a bang. Everyone kept raving about the fried chicken buns though so I'd definitely want to try those!Overall, I really really liked this place and would definitely come back.

20.description: Didn't have any classic tonkotsu options, which is my usually go-to for ramen, but tried out their trademark Spicy Chicken Paitan and surprisingly it still tasted pretty good. That said, as far as ramen goes it wasn't anything that blew me away, and while I suppose I give them some props for making a flavorful broth out of chicken instead of pork, the bowl itself didn't stand out much in other ways; the noodles were just alright and to be honest the portion was smaller than I would have liked(the bowl they serve is essentially a vase in how it narrows out). They did nail the egg and pork though; even though most other ramen shops tend to get the textures for these crucial components down pat, Takeya also has their soft-boiled egg just lightly flavored enough with soy to complement the natural flavor of the ingredients already.

36.description: Ramen was a bit cold and they brought out our entrée when we were only one third through out appetizer.

14.description: What an amazing impromptu lunch!  My friend and I were, literally, wandering aimlessly down Fulton and were looking for a nice lunch place.  She suggest PQM, but, since the wait was a little longer than we wanted to deal with, I told her I remembered that there was a ramen place next door.  Thankfully, she is always down for a bowl of ramen so we popped in.  The restaurant is on the smaller, quaint side, so it was already pretty packed.  Luckily, there were spots open at the bar, so we just sat there.  In a matter of minutes, the remaining empty eats at the bar were snatched up.  The bartender was really nice and informative - he gave suggestions to the couple sitting next to us, so I just listened in since I was interested in the same two dishes.  All the types of ramen looked really good, but I decided on the spicy chicken paitan.  I did a quick read through of other Yelpers and learned that this ramen was creamy.  My friend got the miso hot and spicy.  Other beats any type of spicy ramen, I tell ya.  My spicy chicken was fantastic - amazingly good pork belly, fantastic egg and bamboo shoots.  And the broth?  So so good.  Not overwhelmingly spicy at all and highly addictive. I definitely will be back, but maybe at an off-peak time (if there's ever an off peak time).

3.description: Bought a Groupon for haircut and partial highlights.  Iwona was the stylist and my haircut was style was great.   Coworkers complimented me on the new style.

1.description: It is with a heavy heart that I rate SalonChick at one star.  I walked into the salon at 10:30 and wasn't greeted or acknowledged in anyway.  Seeing that all of the ladies were busy, I sat down and waited.  And waited.  And waited.  There were two nail technicians, one was with a client the whole time and one was not.  At 10:50 I walked over to the technician that was not with a client and asked if she could fit me in for a manicure.  "No" is all she said.  I pointed to the other technician and asked the same question.  "No" again.  No offer to fit me in later, no apologies for the wait.  I stated that I had been here for 20 minutes and that my nails could already be done by now.  She turned and walked away.  As someone who is not a local, I tried Yelping another salon, but was unable to locate one that was in walking distance and open.  I am disappointed in the service and wish that they could have told me right when I walked in that they couldn't fit me in.  I hope that my experience is one in a million and that this is really a great place, but as far as I'm concerned this shop is a no-go

2.description: I'm not sure where to start because this place has aestheticians that each have their own services that they do and prices that they charge. In any case I was able to reach out to the person that does Novalashes here. I have been searching for someone who does specifically this brand of lashes because I love it. I have tried Extreme and Minx, but this is what I prefer because I feel like they don't stick to one another and they last longer like the glue is better. It just feels different in a good way. I have started with it and got really spoiled as a friend in Michigan was doing them and she was a NovaLash Artist of the Year in 2012. The problem has been that I just couldn't get out there all the time. Alexandra/Sasha is one of the women that does do Novalash here in Chicago here at SalonChick. I believe she has been doing lashes for the past 5 years. She is a true sweetheart. She did an excellent job and really listened to what I wanted. I got the dramatic look that I wanted. I will certainly come back to her for my in between fills when I can't get to Michigan. I have only a couple of complaints as she was 20 minutes late for the appointment and I had to stop her midway through the second eye to refill my meter for parking. She also doesn't take credit cards so I had to drive over to the Walgreens to get cash out. This was a bit of a big deal for me as I hate to pay in cash. I like being able to have a record of where I went and spent my money and I like tracking it on my statements. I'd certainly recommend her though, but plan to make extra time and bring cash or a check.

9.description: Love my Eyelash extensions done by Anna. Will be back for sure!!!

10.description: Iwona is an amazing Hairdresser !!! She has been doing my hair for over 5 years. I had my Keratin Treatment done recently for the first time ..which I love !!! She is also excellent with my highlights and haircut, which is why I always go back to her. I would definitely recommend her to anyone I know.

4.description: Sasha is my beauty guru! Get my Nails and eyelashes done only by her. Pleased with amazing work every time. Salon is very clean, warm and beautiful. You cannot find a better place or better services for the price in Chicago. Try it out, you will not regret it!

6.description: This is a very cute neighborhood salon that's worth checking out, I have been going here since it opened few years ago. The nail techs  Karina and Sasha do a great job with manicures and pedicures. The hairstylists Marta and Nadia do great color an cuts. Nina is also a great cosmetologist who does various treatments.

12.description: Anna is great and is a pro at the nova lash application. I have always dreamed of having a full set of lashes that were natural looking and she achieved that and more!! Thanks, Anna!

5.description: Iwona is great! I found a groupon for this salon and was lucky enough to get Iwona as my hairstylist. I went in for a partial highlight and cut and she did a great job! She was very meticulous and took her time. The color and cut turned out great. I will definately be back.

13.description: I've been a loyal customer of Salon Chick since it opened in 2009. I have been getting my haircuts there, pedicures and manicures. Top notch service by best professionals in the industry that really know what they are doing! Lately, I've been a big fan of non-chip manicure! It lasts up to 2-3 weeks and I absolutely love the attention to detail of a nail-technician! Highly recommend to check this spot out!

11.description: Salon chick is an amazing place where you can relax. All of the workers in the salon are really friendly. Once i went there for a manicure. Oleksandra did a great job. I have been visiting Salon Chick for 2 and a half years. I really recommend you to visit salon chick and check out their new Eyelash extensions.

8.description: I had an experience with this Keke girl who claims to be a "hair stylist and color specialist". Yeah right !!! Before we even scheduled an appt. we spoke twice on the phone and I explained what I expected from this appt. Not only did she reschedule my appt. time, she was 20mins. late the day of. My hair; medium brown long layers (layers were grown out a bit) Length to my ears was virgin hair and bottom hair had some color. Once I sat down we went over what we were gonna do, she wanted to try something called "peek-a-boo highlights"  I agreed. First thing she does is cut a chunk of my hair stating "we are not gonna dye this so, Im cutting the length off."  She started to apply the bleach "to lighten the color" .
